questions.stem: Who has the authority to charge a suspect?

options.text: Only the CPS can charge
The custody officer can charge for summary-only and either-way offences; the CPS charges for indictable-only offences
Only the police can charge
Only a magistrate can charge

questions.explanation: The custody officer can charge for summary-only and either-way offences. For indictable-only offences, the CPS must make the charging decision. The custody officer consults with the CPS where appropriate, but the CPS has the final authority for indictable-only offences.

questions.stem: What is the 'threshold test' used by the CPS?

options.text: A test that requires full evidence before charging
A test allowing charge where there is reasonable suspicion and it is in the public interest, even if full evidence is not yet available
A test that only applies to summary offences
A test that is never used

questions.explanation: The threshold test allows the CPS to charge where there is reasonable suspicion that the suspect has committed an offence and it is in the public interest to charge, even if the full code test (sufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction) cannot yet be met. This is used where further investigation is needed but charge is justified.

questions.stem: What is the 'full code test' used by the CPS?

options.text: A test that requires only suspicion
A test requiring sufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction and that prosecution is in the public interest
A test that only applies to police charging decisions
A test that is never used

questions.explanation: The full code test requires: (1) sufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction (evidential test), and (2) that prosecution is in the public interest (public interest test). This is the standard test for charging decisions where full evidence is available.

questions.stem: Can you make representations to the CPS before a charging decision is made?

options.text: No—representations can only be made after charge
Yes—you can make pre-charge representations setting out why charge is not appropriate or why a different charge is more suitable
Only if the CPS requests them
Only for summary offences

questions.explanation: You can and should make pre-charge representations to the CPS where appropriate. This might include: why there is insufficient evidence, why charge is not in the public interest, why a different charge is more appropriate, or highlighting procedural issues. Early representations can prevent inappropriate charges.

questions.stem: After interview, the custody officer is considering whether to charge. What should you do?

options.text: Do nothing—the custody officer will decide
Make representations on bail, charging decisions, and any other relevant matters
Only make representations if asked
Only make representations after charge

questions.explanation: You should proactively make representations on all relevant matters: why charge is not appropriate (if that is the case), bail conditions, and any other issues. This is part of your role in protecting the client's interests and ensuring fair outcomes. Don't wait to be asked—be proactive.
